page.lettertext:
fol.54r
May it please your good L. Upon hope every day to receave aunswear
of
e
States
to her
Ma
ties
demaundes, I have refrained from wri-
ting somewhat longer, then I was willing albeyt I had not mater
since I sent you my last
at might in my opinion deserve the adverti-
sing, and
e lesse a great deale, because I have not yet receaved any
l
re
from your L: whose direction I attend to some pointes of impor-
tance. The answear of
e States is both fully concluded and
[sette] downe in writing, but not contributed yet unto me. For knowing
as I thincke w
at
e tenure will be, That they are not yet in
State to satisfie her Ma
tie
, I have dealt to such effect with some
of
e chiefest of them, as I am done to witte upon it,
at they bethincke
themselves further w
at
special offer they may make,
at would be
[gratefull] to her Hig
es
, whereof I heare by secret meanes,
at they will
make an ouverture unto me, w
th
in fower or fyve dayes: so
at I trust
w
th
my nexte both to send theyr aunswear unto her, and to signifie
at
withall w
ch
they shall determine for better contentation.
Coronel
Stuart
is very earnest in requrying his dispatche, w
ch
yet as farre
as I perceave they doe purposely delay, till they heare w
at
I will say
upon my l
re
s out of
England:
w
ch
I thincke are kept backe by this
Esterly wynde, w
ch
hath continued heere w
th
us for these five weekes to-
gither. He is also very diligent in preferring
e suite of
e
Earle
of Orkney
to
e
La: Emilia
sister to
Co: Maurice
. But
e Count hath
referred him to the Generall States, and
e Assemblie of
e States to
e Ladie her self, who hath aunswered flattly
at she will not
dwell so farre from her brother Co: Maurice and
e rest of her
kindred. Sins
e death of
Ernestus,
there have bin l
re
s
addressed from
e Assemblie of
e States, but in very secret sorte to
e Marquis of Hanery, and to such of nobilitie in
e Enemies[co]
ntry as were co
m
only reputed to be most discontented wth
e gou-
[v]ernment of
e Spaniard to insinuat unto them, at if they were desy-
rous to cast of
at yoke of their Spanish servitude,
ei had
e fittest
[o]pportunitie
at could be expected, and they might make good account
of
e uttermost assistance,
at those of this union could in any kinde
affourde. They retourned this aunswear by a messenger of
purpose. That they would willingly joyne w
t
us, if soe be they
might obtayne
e graunt of these pointes, of their accustomed re-
ligion, of a peace in
France,
and of any course of proceeding for
bannishing
e Spaniard, whether the same were directly or indirectly
procured. It was replyed by
e States by
e self same messenger,
That for mater of religion, they had never no intention to be[reeve]
any Province of
e libertie of conscience: that for France they made
no doubt of inducing
e King to accord a good peace: and
at lastly
they could lyke to have
e Spaniard chased home, by all
e meanes
they could devise. The Marquis upon yt w
t
e rest of
at
syde, sent a couple to Co: Maurice, who repayred unto him about
eight dayes agoe in
e towne of
Middlebourgh,
e one was Mons
r
[Lilsvelt] who hath bin heeretofore a chauncelor in
Brabant:
and
fol.54v
the other was Mons
r
Maute, w
ch
hath in tyme past [been an]
Huissier in
e Chancery. In the deliverie of their [message]
it was apparant to Co: Maurice
at
e Marquis [had acquainted]
de Fuentes
w
th
this practise in soe muche as w[hen they spake of]
expelling
e Spaniard, they proposed how to doe it [with content of the]
King of Spayne
, and by
e meanes of De Fuentes [being]
perceaved by
e Count to bidde them presently de[part. And]
this he hath tould me all himself, being very [desirous that it]
should not be published, least a mater well meant [but per-]
haps misreported by passing many mouthes might [turn to]
their rebuke by whome it was conteyned. T[he]
Duke of Pastr[ava] be arryved at
Brussels,
it is supposed [not]
w
t
standing
at he hath brought no Co
m
ission to c[ommand]
e Contrey. For it is written from Brussels
at [when he]
came to de Fuentes,
e upper hand being offred to [him, he]
would not accept it.
Having no other [mater to signi-]
fie presently, I take my humble leave.
from the Hage.
